posts.title: German Jobs
posts.markdown:
There are some stark differences between working in America and working in Germany (other EU countries as well, but my direct experience is in Germany), which make working in the US seem like a farily ridiculous choice.

**NB** The numbers discussed below may not be _exact_ but they are very close to accurate and can vary by region.

#### Contracts

Just about every job is a contractual agreement between an employee and an employer; usually 2 years or until the employee wishes to leave the company. Normally a 6 month probationary period follows when you move to a new company and a 6-8 week notice period is required (people generally begin new positions on the first of a quarter; if you deviate from this it raises a red flag to a prospective employer).

There is no concept of `At Will Employment` like there is in some horrific US states (aka Michigan); as the Germans say "we don't fire and hire people like Americans".

Overall this is a much better option than contractless American work. It protects and guarentees that they employee is employed.

#### Vacation Time

Varying by company, the minimum is **25 days** of vacation **by law** with larger companies normally having **30 days**. My mom has worked at the same company for 3 decades and almost has that much; can you say "fucking ridiculous"?

Within the contract you agree on the number of hours per week (normally 35 or 40) and time worked over the respective amount of hours per week is banked towards vacation time.

I had 10 days vacation (2 weeks) working at my current job and going to 6 weeks is reason enough to leave for a 3 fold increase.

#### Unions

Something we in the US used to have until we allowed the government to utterly dismantle any type of chance of supporting workers' benefits.

Here they're extreamly strong and work for the employee's benefit, saftey, etc. No they're not perfect, no group of people ever will be, but it's sure a hell of a lot better than **absolutly nothing** in the **USA**.

You have the option to give 1% of your pay to the union which represents you (they're divided into work spheres; not per company like our retarded Walmart/McDonalds/etc. "Unions"). However, even if you don't contribute you _still_ get the benfits.

"So why would I donate?" That's an American question; the culture here understands the value of paying to live in a civilization.

My next section will continue with `M/(P)aternity Leave`, `Part Time Requirements`, and `Applying & Applications`.

Continued @ <http://blog.trollin.pro/german-jobs-part-2/>

posts.title: German Jobs (Part 2)
posts.markdown:
So let's continue off from the last portion:

### M/(P)aternity Leave

That's right unlike most of the barbaric (and frankly somewhat male sexist) leave time given for having a child in the USA: here in Germany both men and women are eligible for leave. Even **both** parents can take time in tandem, although they must work part-time; if a single parent takes his/her leave time then they can not work.

The time I believe depends on the company, but goes from 1-2 **years**: not 1-3 **months** and then _only_ for women, like jobs in the states. From what I understand it's from 60-80% of your base pay, but again this can vary by region and firm.

You also get money from the government when you have a child ~â‚¬183/month (called appropriately `Kindergeld`) which goes up until they are 18.

### Part-Time

Most contracts (see my previous post [here](http://blog.trollin.pro/german-jobs/)) are either 35 or 40 hour work weeks. 35 hours is still considered full time and no it **doesn't** mean you don't get health insurance or any other loss in benefits like KMART tries to do.

Depending on the size of the company (I _believe_ greater than 50 people) by law the company must allow you the option to go to part time at any time you wish. The salary is thus reduced by a percentage of how much time you want to reduce to; so if you worked 40 hours a week and you want to go to 35 you would see a reduction in pay of ~12%.

### Applying & Applications

Well this part you could probably write a book on, but I'm just going to go over some of the main differences I've encountered interviewing here in Germany vs. the USA.

The first major difference is the relative quickness of an answer when you apply for a job; either `yes` or `no` they let you know if they're interested in you or not. That's very unlike my experiences in the US where you'll never hear a response, even after you go to the damn place and interview. #RudeAmericans

Although I only used this at the behest of a very good friend (begrudgingly) the Germans have a standard route for the application _process_ which includes a standard resume as well as cover letter. It is **expected** that one follows this outline (I don't follow process), but this seems to be sanctioned for more "conservative" companies. You can find an example of what this resume looks like here: <http://www.jobscout24.ch/download/vorlagen/Lebenslauf_Marketing.pdf>

You'll notice some strange things (at least for me) which are required and considered normal information to put on here: age (birthday), professionally taken picture, and marital status along with if you have kids or not. Not seen on this one, but also commonly included are: nationality and place of birth. None of which I felt should be required and frankly is rather absurd.

Every time you send in a resume, you also are to send a cover letter (a practice that I never did in the states) with a predetermined structure. That's not totally unlike how they teach us to write cover letters in the states, but again the Germans expect each applicant to have the same structure. This site had a fairly well laid out documentation of what I mean: <http://www.iagora.com/work/en/resumes/letter_germany.html>

Afterwards the interview process is just like any company; they differ totally depending on the company, except these were all in German of course. Then you move on to the contract!

posts.title: Corporation Rights
posts.markdown:
Oftentimes I wonder if people understand what kind of a country they actually live in.

Cases like the recent `Hobby Lobby` ruling outline the ridicuous nature of American thought imo.

We have this idea that on one hand that:

1. The government shouldn't regulate anything
2. Businesses should be able to do what they want
3. People should be able to do what they want

Well oddly you can't have all 3.

You either need to have the government (ideally Federal instead of state or local) regulate what a corporation can and cannot do with respect to its employees. But as we know workers' rights have gone to shit since unions were villified and broken up.

If you don't want the government "restricting" business rights then businesses should be able to do as they please and people can stop bitching about it.

You don't want to work for a Christian organization that spouts Christian values? Then don't work there and stfu. But **as long as the government doesn't regulate** that businesses should have **a seperation of religion** and business or regulate treatment of employees; then you need to **accept the fact** that businesses will run themselves **how they want to be run**.

How do people propose both point #2 and #3 to exist? They're mutually exclusive, or rather I'd certainly strongly argue they are (keep your corner/edge cases to yourself).

People think they should be able to call out these businesses as villians, because they are "impeding" on the employees rights. But at the same time the same people are claiming we shouldn't regulate businesses.

Guess what? That means you just went **#fullretard**.

If you're not for federal regulation of business practices, either via unions or public discourse then you're also not for workers' rights and you have nothing to complain about.

These dumb people think a `free market` in a `capitalistic` system will benefit employees and they keep on defending it.

Well guess what, you reap what you sow.

posts.title: A Bit of Belgium
posts.markdown: I spent last week with two of my friends who live in Belgium ~30 minutes outside Ghent in a small "village", which even though the weather was blah was a pretty awesome time overall. ## Cities They showed me two cities: Ghent and Bruges, both of which were fairly similiar in their layout. Canals throughout the city, castles, typical European towns albeit they differed quite drastically from the German towns I'm used to seeing. _Ghent_ The `stacked` style on the buildings seems quite common. I'd highly recommend doing the 30-40 minute canal tours which are only around 7â‚¬. They didn't seem to apt to speak German, however, our guide in Ghent who was also hot as well as entertaining spoke Spanish, English, French, and Dutch. The small village where we stayed of course had significantly less (aka only me) tourists than the cities we visitied. Cities accepted credit cards moreso than German ones and they were also pretty clean aside from the Brussels main train station which was horrible. ## Language I had thought my German would help as I figured they'd know German before English, but that proved to be totally incorrect. Although I could understand ~20-30% of what they spoke in Dutch using the apropriate German counterpart. Basically Dutch sounds like you're trying to throw up or have something stuck in your throat that needs to come out. It certainly has German roots (I think it belongs to the Proto-Germanic family, but too lazy to look atm) mixed with French and cocaine. For instance: >(English) _I am tired_ > (German) _Ich bin mÃ¼de_ > (Dutch) _Ik ben moe_ So in Dutch you make the sound of a cow to signify you would like to sleep. But that's just one small example, sadly the rest is not anything like German otherwise it'd be really simple to swap. The verb `mÃ¶chte`: "would like" in German, but in Dutch has the opposite meaning `moeten` of "to need". **Not** the same word, but they phonetically sound the same, as well as resemble one another. The phonetics also throw me off where "thank you" (German `danke`) goes to `dank je` in Dutch, but the `je` doesn't sound like the French `je` like I'd think. It's more of a `yur` (/jÉ™/): ## Beer Best for last? One of my most surprising findings was just the crazy amounts of beer they have in Belgium. And that each fucking beer has a glass counterpart to go with it, not just a brand name on it, but unique freaking glasses like this one `Quark`: Literally hundreds of these types of beers and some of my favorites having gnomes plastered on them. The alcoholic content is much higher than that of the German beers which are typically 4.5-6%, but can get to 8%. On the flip side the Belgian beers seem to start around 7% and go up to 11 or 12% I can't remember which the bartender said was the upper limit. I asked my local boys doing their Ausbildung at the Hyatt why we don't see any Belgian beers in Germany, because I was a bit perplexed. They explained that you have to have a special license in order to sell them due to the high alcoholic content and that when you do you as a company are liable for the patrons actions afterwards. And since you can drink beer at 16 in Germany (which I'm fairly sure you can also in Belgium) they claimed that too many kids were dying from chugging the high alcohol content beer. Which makes **perfect sense** given how small Belgium is, great population control idea imo. That's a good snippet for now of random bullshit I learned in Belgium.

I spent last week with two of my friends who live in Belgium ~30 minutes outside Ghent in a small "village", which even though the weather was blah was a pretty awesome time overall.

Cities

They showed me two cities: Ghent and Bruges, both of which were fairly similiar in their layout. Canals throughout the city, castles, typical European towns albeit they differed quite drastically from the German towns I'm used to seeing.

Ghent

The stacked style on the buildings seems quite common.

I'd highly recommend doing the 30-40 minute canal tours which are only around 7â‚¬. They didn't seem to apt to speak German, however, our guide in Ghent who was also hot as well as entertaining spoke Spanish, English, French, and Dutch.

The small village where we stayed of course had significantly less (aka only me) tourists than the cities we visitied.

Cities accepted credit cards moreso than German ones and they were also pretty clean aside from the Brussels main train station which was horrible.

Language

I had thought my German would help as I figured they'd know German before English, but that proved to be totally incorrect. Although I could understand ~20-30% of what they spoke in Dutch using the apropriate German counterpart.

Basically Dutch sounds like you're trying to throw up or have something stuck in your throat that needs to come out.

It certainly has German roots (I think it belongs to the Proto-Germanic family, but too lazy to look atm) mixed with French and cocaine.

For instance:

(English) I am tired

(German) Ich bin mÃ¼de

(Dutch) Ik ben moe

So in Dutch you make the sound of a cow to signify you would like to sleep.

But that's just one small example, sadly the rest is not anything like German otherwise it'd be really simple to swap. The verb mÃ¶chte: "would like" in German, but in Dutch has the opposite meaning moeten of "to need". Not the same word, but they phonetically sound the same, as well as resemble one another.

The phonetics also throw me off where "thank you" (German danke) goes to dank je in Dutch, but the je doesn't sound like the French je like I'd think. It's more of a yur (/jÉ™/):

Beer

Best for last? One of my most surprising findings was just the crazy amounts of beer they have in Belgium. And that each fucking beer has a glass counterpart to go with it, not just a brand name on it, but unique freaking glasses like this one Quark:

Literally hundreds of these types of beers and some of my favorites having gnomes plastered on them.

The alcoholic content is much higher than that of the German beers which are typically 4.5-6%, but can get to 8%. On the flip side the Belgian beers seem to start around 7% and go up to 11 or 12% I can't remember which the bartender said was the upper limit.

I asked my local boys doing their Ausbildung at the Hyatt why we don't see any Belgian beers in Germany, because I was a bit perplexed. They explained that you have to have a special license in order to sell them due to the high alcoholic content and that when you do you as a company are liable for the patrons actions afterwards.

And since you can drink beer at 16 in Germany (which I'm fairly sure you can also in Belgium) they claimed that too many kids were dying from chugging the high alcohol content beer. Which makes perfect sense given how small Belgium is, great population control idea imo.

That's a good snippet for now of random bullshit I learned in Belgium.

posts.title: Double Standard Queerality
posts.markdown:
One of my good friends was telling me that I should watch this movie: [Freier Fall](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2617828/). While I haven't taken his suggestion up yet, I did read a bit about the plot and the movie which seems to be yet another 
>guy has wife and kids, falls in love with another man and tries to find himself

I frankly don't care for these types of movies, I usually find them to be utlradramatic and edge case realistic.

Either way, movie aside the plot had me thinking about the duality there seems to be between when a man (NB I've never seen this with women in media other than maybe The Color Purple) either implicitly or explicity identifies as straight and then "finds himself" and then begins to identify as gay.

This seems to be a typical scenario that some people find themselves in. And when popularized in the media the attention that is gained is that of support, acceptance, and a general applause at "finding oneself". In that he has somehow came to the conclusion that he was confused previously, or now has the balls to say what his inclination _actually_ is. 

**That's a great thing** to have in a community: acceptance, support, and tolerance.

But at least from what I see popularized in the media (which has its own agenda of course) the opposite seems to be demonized; that is when a man who either explicitly or implicitly identified as gay "finds himself" to be straight.

It's quite perplexing to me that this "revelation" seems to be a one way street.

Of course I've seen the crazy nutcases who try electroshock therapy on weak individuals who want to be "cured" as if an inclination is a sort of disease, but this isn't the crazy stuff I'm talking about (we've all seen [But I'm A Cheerleader](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0179116/)).

What the oddity I am trying to clarify is why is it when an identified homo decides that s/he is actually inclined to like the opposite gender that they seem to be demonized or put into an air of suspicion as if they are somehow under duress and are being forced to "revert back".

Because, if we have the one side where as I previously mentioned someone "comes out", why is the opposite procedure is treated as if it's caused by a weak individual: met with skepticism. 

A man who has a wife and kids (married even) and then decides he really likes guys is met with total acceptance [by the gay community] (I won't go in to my criticisms on that) and assurance; the exact opposite is met with the reversed situation.

I don't have any direct articles to reference, even though I'm sure they're easy to find. Just a simple musing into what I consider to be a rather odd difference of reactions to the same procedures.
